Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the involvement of Bill Gates and other globalists in pushing for tracking bracelets and invisible tattoos to monitor Americans during an impending lockdown. There is no evidence to support this assertion.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no evidence to suggest that Bill Gates is pushing for tracking bracelets or that the MIT research is related to tracking Americans during the pandemic.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that Bill Gates and other globalists are collaborating with pharmaceutical companies to push for tracking bracelets and invisible tattoos, without providing any evidence to support this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert's verdict provides an alternative explanation by stating that the research into invisible ink technology was funded by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation to strengthen vaccination record-keeping in developing countries, rather than for tracking purposes.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the MIT research on invisible ink technology began in July 2016, more than three years before the first novel coronavirus cases emerged. It was not inspired by the current outbreak.
Understate: There is no evidence to suggest that the claim understates any information or downplays any aspects of the situation.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by making unsupported assertions and distorting the timeline of the research funded by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation.
